First of all you're modifying an autogenerated file.

Second, this file includes all of moment + all locales. So the code you're modifying is never executed. So there is no problem :)

Issue Title: locale changes does'nt work
Author: mattjohnsonpint
Comment Body:
Read through the ["Where to use it"](http://momentjs.com/docs/#/use-it/) section of the docs and see if any of those scenarios apply to you.  In general, you either need to be using `moment-with-locales.js`, or have loaded the locale data separately.  Most loaders will not automatically pick up the language file, so you may need to import them separately.

Basically, if you try to switch to a locale that's not loaded, moment will revert to the `en` locale.

Issue Title: locale changes does'nt work
Author: mattjohnsonpint
Comment Body: See also ["Loading locales in the browser"](http://momentjs.com/docs/#/i18n/loading-into-browser/).

I then use it with a single import:

I'll post the result of my experiments.
Thanks

Issue Title: Invalid date for format "YYYYMMDDHHMMSS"
Author: DaSchTour
Comment Body: Just a guess. It has something todo with 12 and 24 hour format.

Issue Title: Invalid date for format "YYYYMMDDHHMMSS"
Author: maggiepint
Comment Body:
I think the format that you want is 'YYYYMMDDHHmmss'

Right now you're using the months token (MM) twice, and the second token is parsing and setting months a second time, as a number greater than 12, ergo your date is invalid. The proper token for minutes is 'mm'.
In addition SS is a token for fractional seconds, but I believe you have whole seconds which are represented by 'ss'.

The following works fine:

``` js
moment('20160307133625','YYYYMMDDHHmmss').format()
"2016-03-07T13:36:25-06:00"
```

Issue Title: Invalid date for format "YYYYMMDDHHMMSS"
Author: luoye00
Comment Body:
> I think the format that you want is 'YYYYMMDDHHmmss'
> 
> Right now you're using the months token (MM) twice, and the second token is parsing and setting months a second time, as a number greater than 12, ergo your date is invalid. The proper token for minutes is 'mm'. In addition SS is a token for fractional seconds, but I believe you have whole seconds which are represented by 'ss'.
> 
> The following works fine:
> 
> ```js
> moment('20160307133625','YYYYMMDDHHmmss').format()
> "2016-03-07T13:36:25-06:00"
> ```

This ok for me

Issue Title: .fromNow() does not respect current locale setting
Author: ichernev
Comment Body:
Well, setting the global locale only changes the locale for newly created moments. And because you have one test object, it creates.

Now the other thing is that when you clone a `moment` object by `moment(m)`, you preserve the locale of `m`, so even though the locale for new moments is `en` you keep the `de` locale that `m` has (`this.start` and `this.end` in your example).

Issue Title: .fromNow() does not respect current locale setting
Author: s-a
Comment Body:
For me it looked like that `moment.locale()` is a public setup in moments environment for all instances. So it was not my expected bahavior. 
I solved my problem by calling `.locale()` method everytime before using `.fromNow()` function.  `moment(this.start).locale(moment.locale()).fromNow()`. 

This works for me, but feels a little bit strange. http://jsfiddle.net/s__a/ceu9kqt6/3/

Issue Title: .fromNow() does not respect current locale setting
Author: ichernev
Comment Body: Changing everything created with a single call is also kind of weird. It was the behavior for some time but we rewrote the locale logic in 2.7 or 2.8. In the future we'll have a way for you to create a moment with the `global` locale -- that will follow and change as the global locale changes (but explicitly).

Issue Title: .fromNow() does not respect current locale setting
Author: maggiepint
Comment Body: Closing due to age. Let us know if this is still an issue and you would like it re-opened.

Author: benadamstyles
Comment Body: If you don't want to use `moment-with-locales`, which loads all locale data, rolling back to moment v2.18 fixed this for me. There is definitely a bug with moment v2.20 and setting the locale in react native.

Issue Title: How to change locale in momentJS in React Native?
Author: msevestre
Comment Body:
@Leeds-eBooks Could you explain how you import moment? I rolled back to 2.18 and yet I need to import moment from moment-with-locales in to get local to work properly in react-native

Thanks

Issue Title: How to change locale in momentJS in React Native?
Author: benadamstyles
Comment Body:
@msevestre Yeah of course, although I think my solution may be out of date now, I made it work in my code and moved on, I think a later version of moment might have fixed it. Nevertheless, my fix is:

- install `https://github.com/tqc/moment.git#no-dynamic-import` from git, instead of `moment` directly from npm
- then:

```js
import moment from 'moment'

import 'moment/src/locale/en-gb'
import 'moment/src/locale/es'
import 'moment/src/locale/fr'
import 'moment/src/locale/pl'
import 'moment/src/locale/pt'
// ...etc

// bonus trick!
import DeviceInfo from 'react-native-device-info'
const deviceLocale = DeviceInfo.getDeviceLocale()
moment.locale([deviceLocale, 'en'])
```

This is what I'm doing, and it's working for me, but as I say it may no longer be necessary.

Issue Title: How to change locale in momentJS in React Native?
Author: RicardoBer
Comment Body:
Check this:

```
import moment from "moment";
import 'moment/min/locales'
```
This include all languajes configurations from moment, it's js, so no problem with size.

I had problem before when some one install the app with an mobile with different languaje.

From this you can set any locale defined by moment without any problem, 

`moment.locale('es');`

Or using device locale without worries about it is out of your languajes specs as example from @benadamstyles

Issue Title: How to change locale in momentJS in React Native?
Author: Asday
Comment Body:
`import 'moment/src/locale/en-gb'` didn't work for me, but `import 'moment/locale/en-gb'` did.

```JSON
  "dependencies": {
    "expo": "32.0.0",
    "moment": "2.24.0",
    "react": "16.5.0",
    "react-native": "https://github.com/expo/react-native/archive/sdk-32.0.0.tar.gz"
  },
```

In the upper-most file in the tree, here's how my code looks:

```es6
import moment from 'moment'

import 'moment/locale/en-gb'

const momentLocale = moment.locale('en-gb')
if (momentLocale !== 'en-gb') {
  throw new Error(`Moment fell back to locale ${momentLocale}`)
}

export default () => null
```

In other words `moment.locale()` is setting the locale to the local instance of `moment` and NOT GLOBAL.

Author: AmirDiafi

**this is what you look for:**

```
import * as RNLocalize from 'react-native-localize'
const local = RNLocalize.getLocales()
const lanTag = local[0].languageTag.toLowerCase()
console.log(lanTag)
import moment from 'moment'
import 'moment/min/locales'
moment.locale(lanTag) //set moment local
```

take look this guide  : https://momentjs.com/guides/#/warnings/define-locale/

bellow is working for me :

```JS
import moment from 'moment'
moment.defineLocale('id',{
  months : [
    'Januari',
    'Februari',
    'Maret',
    'April',
    'Mei',
    'Juni',
    'Juli',
    'Agustus',
    'September',
    'Oktober',
    'November',
    'Desember',
  ],
  //etc opts
})
```

Issue Title: moment cannot always parse moment default formatted negative years
Author: icambron
Comment Body: Yeah, there's probably a bug in the ISO parser there. Would be happy to take a fix.

Issue Title: moment cannot always parse moment default formatted negative years
Author: ichernev
Comment Body:
That is a weird one. If you use `toISOString()`, then it correctly outputs `-000001`, which can then be correctly parsed.

`format()` uses a default format with `YYYY`, that would then output `-0001`, which can then not be strictly parsed into ISO, because ISO forbids 4 digits with a sign, and states you should use more (and in moment we stick with 6 digits in this case).

On the other hand there is the problem that `YYYY` does not parse any leading signs, so if you have year : `y < 0 || y > 9999` it won't be parsed correctly with `YYYY`, even though it was formatted with `YYYY`.

If we change the way `YYYY` parsing works, it will break for cases like `'20151209', 'YYYYMMDD'`, because `YYYY` can in theory consume more than 4 digits (if the input was bigger), and this case is far more likely than the case with an year bigger than `9999` or negative. Only supporting negative is going to fix the issue presented here, but won't fix years above `9999`, or below `-9999`.
- So if the concern is `format() produces something unparsable` we can fix format to use `YYYYYY` instead for weird years.
- If the issue is that format('YYYY') can not be parsed with 'YYYY', then we can only (maybe) fix that for `y in (-9999, -1)`, because the other option is impossible.
- If the issue is that `-0001-...` is not valid ISO ... not sure what to do here, as the docs don't really specify anything about years below 1583, except "the parties should reach an agreement". So if the agreement was to use ISO string (`toISOString` not `format`), this is a non-issue.

Issue Title: moment cannot always parse moment default formatted negative years
Author: marwahaha
Comment Body: I think both 1 and 2 are important. I feel like being able to parse whatever the default to `format` is an important guideline. Plus, the symmetry is important (format->YYYY should parse with YYYY).

Issue Title: moment cannot always parse moment default formatted negative years
Author: MichaelYogar
Comment Body: Hi, I'm looking to make my first open source contribution. If nobody is working on this, I can try to solve this issue.

I use in webpack from [this page](https://webpack.js.org/plugins/ignore-plugin/)
```javascript
new IgnorePlugin(/^\.\/locale$/, /moment$/)
```
Now remove it

And in require
```javascript
const moment = require('moment');
```
Now
```javascript
const moment = require('moment').default;
```

Same here - I fixed it with a feature of yarn to overload the default settings of a package:

place this in your main package.json (adapt "moment-timezone" to the name of the package which does load moment if you do not directly load moment):
```

    "moment-timezone/moment": "2.18.1"
  },
```

Issue Title: Webpack Error: Cannot find module "./locale" after updating to 2.19.0
Author: arsyed04
Comment Body: What is the ETA for fix?

Issue Title: Webpack Error: Cannot find module "./locale" after updating to 2.19.0
Author: maggiepint
Comment Body:
Okay, here's where we're at:

+ If you set your dependency to 2.18.1, everything will be fine.
+ This is an issue with https://github.com/moment/moment/pull/4213
+ I have engaged both the webpack and react native teams to talk about what fix will work for all parties
+ Because setting the dependency to 2.18.1 provides an easy mitigation, I do not at this time want to roll back. Instead, I would like to wait on feedback from Webpack and React Native to see if we can come to an agreement about what to do that will move this situation *forward*. For that reason, I don't have an ETA on a fix.
+ A MCVE can be found here: https://github.com/mj1856/moment-webpack-test

Issue Title: Webpack Error: Cannot find module "./locale" after updating to 2.19.0
Author: rbalmf
Comment Body:
@ichernev seems very likely that the rename of 'require' is causing these widespread breakages.  I suspect that when you require modules using a reference like that it means that webpack is unable to detect the import since it uses AST static analysis to determine dependencies.

Perhaps you could provide some details of the React Native issue it was fixing as there might be some better way around that original issue?

Issue Title: Library uses code from stackoverflow.com
Author: icambron
Comment Body: Not a lawyer, but I think it means that the specific code derived from SO answers is distributed under Creative Commons, not the whole library. Perhaps we need to do a) a better job with attribution and ~~b) a better job of specifying the license for those specific pieces of code~~ (edit: doesn't look like we need to do that; see Matt's link below), ~~and we'd welcome qualified help for sorting that out~~ (edit: doesn't seem necessary). But that's different from Moment as a whole being CC. All that out of the way, is there a specific reason that the MIT license doesn't fit your needs?

Issue Title: Library uses code from stackoverflow.com
Author: mattjohnsonpint
Comment Body:
It will not affect your license.  We are licensing all code in this project under the MIT license.  All contributions to this project are released by their contributors under that license.  It does not matter where the technique was learned from.

With regard to actual code snippets, those are being used in accordance with the fair use doctrine.

Additionally, Creative Commons is a _content_ license.  It only applies to the _publication_ of the material, such as when viewing the source code. If you took large chunks of code from a CC licensed project and pasted them on your blog without any attribution, then you would be in violation.  But you can put that same source code into your project and ship your product under whatever license you wish without any attribution whatsoever.

At least that's my interpretation. I am not a lawyer.

There are plenty of discussions on this on StackOverflow's Meta site.

Issue Title: Library uses code from stackoverflow.com
Author: mattjohnsonpint
Comment Body:
Also see: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2009/06/attribution-required/  Which says in part:

> So let me clarify what we mean by attribution. **If you republish this content**, we require that you...

(emphasis mine)

Issue Title: Library uses code from stackoverflow.com
Author: gmpuran
Comment Body:
Hi Team,

Just wanted to touch base on this issue again, as per legal page on the StackOverflow site:

https://stackoverflow.com/legal/terms-of-service/public#licensing

It basically says that the "Subscriber Content" is licensed under CC-By-SA as well. 

Would it then affect the license for this library and the license of any commercial applications using this library?

Please advise.

Thanks in advance!

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: mattjohnsonpint
Comment Body:
You can always take individual locale files [from here](https://github.com/moment/moment/tree/develop/locale).

The docs describe [how to load them](http://momentjs.com/docs/#/i18n/loading-into-nodejs/)

But I think what you're asking is how to load them individually via npm?  I'm not sure if that's possible without having a separate npm package for each locale.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: schovi
Comment Body:
I described my problem badly. Another try :)

In my app I installed momentjs with `npm install moment` and require it `var moment  = require('moment')`
Then it automatically require all locales for some reason. In Webpack log it is described 

```
[239] ./~/moment/moment.js 104 kB {0} {1} [built]
[240] ./~/moment/locale ^\.\/.*$ 2.06 kB {0} {1} [optional] [built]
[241] ./~/moment/locale/af.js 2.58 kB {0} {1} [optional] [built]
[242] ./~/moment/locale/ar.js 4.52 kB {0} {1} [optional] [built]
```

For some reason and I cant find in momentjs source why it require all locales with this `./~/moment/locale ^\.\/.*$`

What i want is to require only `moment` and separatly `moment/locale/cs` and `moment/locale/en-gb`

Any suggestion?

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: ichernev
Comment Body:
@schovi I'm not familiar with webpack, but you can do the following experiment. 

1) Put a console.log into one of the locale files.

``` patch
--- /home/iskren/src/moment/locale/fr.js    2015-07-27 21:37:05.000000000 -0700
+++ locale/fr.js    2015-07-30 21:53:41.833619994 -0700
@@ -8,6 +8,8 @@
    factory(global.moment)
 }(this, function (moment) { 'use strict';

+    console.log("hello world");
+

     var fr = moment.defineLocale('fr', {
         months : 'janvier_février_mars_avril_mai_juin_juillet_août_septembre_octobre_novembre_décembre'.split('_'),
```

2) Require moment.js (via node command line) and verify it is NOT printed

``` bash
$ node
> require("./moment")
// prints moment properties, but no "hello world"
```

3) Optionally require the locale to see that it IS printed

``` bash
$ node
> require("./locale/fr.js")
hello world
{}
```

So this means Webpack is at fault and not the way we package moment. `jspm` and `spm` sections in `package.json` list locale as a thing, maybe it is related. Check Webpack source code, ask in their bug trackers ... etc :)

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: ichernev
Comment Body: @mj1856 just to be clear, the locale files are shipped with npm, so he should find them in his `node_modules/moment/locale` directory at best, not in the git repo (they are also in the git repo, but for npm users that is irrelevant).

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: schovi
Comment Body: Thanks for answer, will try to dig in webpack.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: rattrayalex
Comment Body: FWIW, the size of the "moment" package shrinks from 364.36kB to 101.97kB (second-largest to fourth-largest package, going from twice-as-large to half-as-big as our company codebase itself) when I don't include the locales (done hackily by commenting out `require('./locale/' + name);` in `moment.js`). We don't use this feature at our company, so I'd love a supported way not to include these in our webpack bundle.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: mrberggg
Comment Body:
I suggest reopening this as it's not fixed. For anyone else looking for a fix, I found one [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25384360/how-to-prevent-moment-js-from-loading-locales-with-webpack). In your webpack config, add the following to your plugins array: 

`new webpack.ContextReplacementPlugin(/moment[\/\\]locale$/, /en/)`

This is pretty hacky, dependent on that particular include not changing. An official method would be ideal. Could you perhaps add a `moment` section to the `package.json` file for config options, with an array of desired locales?

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: pbrain19
Comment Body: The solution proposed looks great if you only use english. but what about the scenario you want to support all the moment js but only want to load the one you need to the browsers. The Dynamic loading works but it is inefficient in that it bundles all the locales to one bundle. When the bundle is requested it is essentially downloading the entire file. Has anyone found a good way such that that we only dynamically load the one you need? The only solution I see is making a locales.js file and that being a giant if else statement with one branch for each language file. tedious but would solve the issue of only loading the file I need.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: exoer
Comment Body:
import "moment/locale/fr"
    import "moment/locale/de"

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: pbrain19
Comment Body: For anyone that cares in the future. The solution which resulted to be the least hacky was to use the suggested `new webpack.ContextReplacementPlugin(/moment[\/\\]locale$/, /en/)` to only load my default language and then have my builder copy the moment files into a public folder. My browser app then requests the one it before it loads.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?

Comment Body:

https://github.com/moment/moment/issues/1435#issuecomment-187100876

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: pbrain19
Comment Body: From a browsers perspective it will still bundle and load it to the browser. This is not the ideal behavior we want in the browser. The answer there only explains how to bundle the locales you want. What I was looking for was an ability to support all locales without loading them all to the browser.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: Mat-thieu

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: eigood
Comment Body:
The following snippet keeps the default en.js, en-*.js, and moment source in the primary bundles/entry points, while mapping all other locale files into a separate async loaded bundle.

To ensure that the locales you need are available, you just need to import them into your es6-compatible file.  If you don't know what those are ahead of time, then there are existing runtime delay load things you can use; we use `react-loadable`.

Before:

```
         common-lazy-main.0.86c95acc47616cc81c89.bundle.js.gz     102 kB
```

After:

```
   locale-not-en-main.1.8f31af252992c69da121.bundle.js.gz    46.8 kB
     common-lazy-main.0.603eebddcd2bcf32c0d3.bundle.js.gz    54.5 kB
```


```
10:51:22 -0600 adam@tooz(MLO-63|REBASE-i):XXXX/react-player-prototype$ git diff HEAD^ HEAD
diff --git a/webpack.config.js b/webpack.config.js
index a11d0ed..395b7b3 100644
--- a/webpack.config.js
+++ b/webpack.config.js
@@ -79,9 +79,22 @@ let plugins = [
     'analyzer',
     'srcReplacement',
 ]
+const momentNotEnLocales = /node_modules\/moment\/locale\/(?!en-?).*\.js$/
 const splittingPlugins = [
     new webpack.optimize.AggressiveMergingPlugin(),
     new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin({
+        async: 'locale-not-en',
+        minChunks(module) {
+            const {context, resource} = module
+            if (resource) {
+                if (resource.match(momentNotEnLocales)) {
+                    return true
+                }
+            }
+            return false
+        },
+    }),
+    new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin({
         name: 'vendor',
         minChunks(module) {
             return module.context && module.context.indexOf("node_modules") !== -1
```

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: JamesPlayer
Comment Body:
The solution here looks a little cleaner: https://medium.com/@michalozogan/how-to-split-moment-js-locales-to-chunks-with-webpack-de9e25caccea

```
# webpack config
...
plugins: [
    new webpack.IgnorePlugin(/^\.\/locale$/, /moment$/),
],
...
```

Then you can just import the ones you want
```
import 'moment/locale/cs.js';
import 'moment/locale/es.js';
```

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: arcataroger
Comment Body:
For anyone still dealing with this issue in 2020, there is now a webpack plugin that lets you define which locales you need (defaults to "en" only) and removes the rest:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/moment-locales-webpack-plugin

It has a sister package to strip out unnecessary timezones from moment-timezone:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/moment-timezone-data-webpack-plugin

Between the two, we shaved off 800 kB of unnecessary size.

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?

Issue Title: How to load only locales i want?
Author: phil294
Comment Body:
@brendon regarding **Vite**:

I'm not sure why, but this seems to simply not be necessary. Nothing is bundled in the output module, unless you explicitly import it. https://github.com/moment/moment/issues/5926

```js
import moment from 'moment'
import 'moment/dist/locale/fr'

console.log(moment('2012 juillet', 'YYYY MMM', 'fr').format())
```

Issue Title: Security issue with the usage of \\ inside replace method
Author: gilmoreorless
Comment Body: There are some key details missing here. What is the actual vulnerability you're reporting? What is the impact? Is there a link to a vulnerability report somewhere?

Issue Title: Security issue with the usage of \\ inside replace method
Author: srinivas3793
Comment Body:
@gilmoreorless Pls check the codeql link for the issue description https://codeql.github.com/codeql-query-help/javascript/js-incomplete-sanitization/

Moment pkg file which I'm reporting is violating above security checks in the file https://github.com/moment/moment/blob/18aba135ab927ffe7f868ee09276979bed6993a6/src/lib/parse/regex.js#L69

Issue Title: Security issue with the usage of \\ inside replace method
Author: gilmoreorless
Comment Body:
I think you've misunderstood what the linked code does. The CodeQL link is warning about incomplete **escaping**, but the `unescapeFormat` function does the _opposite_ of escaping — it's stripping away certain escaping characters **then passing them to the `regexEscape` function** to do the proper escaping.

Additionally, `unescapeFormat` only runs on small tokens that have already been broken apart by the regex at https://github.com/moment/moment/blob/18aba135ab927ffe7f868ee09276979bed6993a6/src/lib/format/format.js#L4-L5

Static code analysers can only make inferences based on patterns, but won't always know the full context of the code. They're very helpful for catching potential bugs, but they do also have false positives. This is one of those times.
Blindly following the reports of a static analyser 100% can sometimes lead to problems, in the same way as completely ignoring them. Context always has to be taken into account.

Issue Title: Changed timezone 'Asia/Almaty' wat +6 => now +5
Author: caryyu
Comment Body: @ichernev any thoughts on this? guess it's a universal issue.

Issue Title: Changed timezone 'Asia/Almaty' wat +6 => now +5
Author: gilmoreorless
Comment Body: If you're using just Moment by itself, it will use whatever time zone definitions are provided by the host environment (browser, NodeJS, etc.). If you're using the Moment Timezone addon, the latest version handles the Kazakhstan changes correctly.

Issue Title: moment/moment
Author: gilmoreorless
Comment Body: Please don't create junk issues; you waste a lot of people's time.

Issue Title: Glob version deprecated
Author: gilmoreorless
Comment Body: Moment doesn't use `glob` directly. It's brought in by other packages, which Moment only specifies in `devDependencies`. This means they're only installed when working in the `moment` project root — they are not installed when `moment` is installed as a dependency.

Issue Title: React-Native Release Builds, Deep Crash when changing locales
Author: fbartho
Comment Body:
The referenced lines are "automatically" trying to require modules at runtime, but the [loading locales docs](https://momentjs.com/docs/#/i18n/loading-into-browser/) indicate that if you're using a Package Manager like JSPM, you can load locales by `import "moment/locale/fr`. Since we need the react-native package manager to "know" that the file must be imported, we tried that style of import so that the Packager can "see" all files that have to be bundled in.

Ultimately, our import lines looked like this:

```typescript
import moment from "moment";
import "moment/min/locales"; // Import all moment-locales -- it's just 400kb
import "moment-timezone";
```

The exact implementation of `require()` is injected by the runtime you're working with, and that's definitely something that behaves significantly differently between Debug & Release builds.

In react-native, there are also several different flavors of Release-mode JavaScript Bundling, including all-in-one-file, all-in-separate-files, and RAM Bundles. Each of these also change how require works. Debug `require()` connects to the [Metro Bundler](https://facebook.github.io/metro/) running on a local http server. This is probably is very similar to the webpack/jspm/other debug servers, which is probably why aliasing require doesn't cause problems in that environment.

Issue Title: React-Native Release Builds, Deep Crash when changing locales
Author: fbartho
Comment Body:
## My Fix Proposals:

A. Delete the `aliasedRequire` entirely if that's not how you're supposed to do things any more + tweak install instructions about it?
B. Detect react-native vs browser (`navigator` isn't available in react-native, but there are other techniques here), and behave differently depending on which situation we find ourselves in? eg. if react-native && DEV then print a console.error if the locale is theoretically supported, but hasn't been `required` yet (+ update docs).
C. Move the `aliasedRequire` from a local variable in that function to a "semi-global". `moment.aliasedRequire`, that way we could inject a no-op/do-nothing function so that `aliasedRequire` can't cause react-native to crash hard anymore.

Issue Title: React-Native Release Builds, Deep Crash when changing locales
Author: fbartho
Comment Body: I'd be happy to implement any of these options if a maintainer can point me at which one they would like me to implement, and for Proposals B/C help me refine which exact implementation they would be inclined to accept!

Issue Title: React-Native Release Builds, Deep Crash when changing locales
Author: fbartho
Comment Body: @marwahaha -- not sure what the process is for Moment. Would you have an opinion on my fix proposals? I'd be happy to implement a PR once I get some advice on which route might be acceptable to contributors/maintainers?

Issue Title: React-Native Release Builds, Deep Crash when changing locales
Author: joe06102
Comment Body:
if anyone meets such errors as **"can not find module './locale/xxx' in react-native production build"**，

**try to import the locale files manually**.

eg: 
```javascript
import * as zh from 'moment/locale/zh-cn';
```

As far as I know, dynamic require is not supported in the **Metro** packager, which causes such errors.
